lesson.name: Lesson 7.11: Graphing from the Factored Form

page.title: 7.11.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will evaluate expressions at certain \(x\)-values to see if they produce an output of \(0\). You will learn what the factored form can tell us about the vertex and the \(y\)-intercept of a graph representing a quadratic function.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Graph a quadratic function given in factored form.
  • Find the vertex and \(y\)-intercept of the graph of a quadratic function in factored form without graphing it first.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.11.1: Finding Coordinates
  • 7.11.2: The Factored Form of a Quadratic Expression and the \(X\)-Intercepts of Its Graph
    • 7.11.2: Self Check
    • 7.11.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.11.3: Sketching a Graph of a Quadratic Function Using at Least Three Identifiable Points
    • 7.11.3: Self Check
    • 7.11.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.11.4: Graphs of Quadratic Functions

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.11.5: Practice
  • 7.11.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.11.1: Finding Coordinates
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Here is a graph of a function \(w\) defined by \(w(x)=(x+1.6)(x-2)\). Three points on the graph are labeled.

Use the graph to answer the following questions.

  1. Find the value of \(a\). Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -1.6

The correct answer is -1.6.

  1. Find the value of \(b\). Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 0

The correct answer is 0.

  1. Find the value of \(c\). Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 2

The correct answer is 2.

  1. Find the value of \(d\). Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 0

The correct answer is 0.

  1. Find the value of \(e\). Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 0

The correct answer is 0.

  1. Find the value of \(f\). Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -3.2

The correct answer is -3.2.

page.title: 7.11.2: The Factored Form of a Quadratic Expression and the X-Intercepts of Its Graph
page.contents:
Activity

Consider two functions defined by \(f(x)=x(x+4)\) and \(g(x)=x(x-4)\).

  1. Consider the function defined by \(f(x)=x(x+4)\).

Use the table to answer questions a–g to complete the table of values for the function.

\(x\)

\(f(x)\)

-5

5

-4

-3

b. _____

-1

-3

    1. When the value of \(x=-4\), what is the value of \(f(x)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 0

The correct answer is 0.

    1. When the value of \(x=-3\), what is the value of \(f(x)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -3

The correct answer is -3.

    1. When the value of \(x=0\), what is the value of \(f(x)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 0

The correct answer is 0.

    1. When the value of \(x=1\), what is the value of \(f(x)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 5

The correct answer is 5.

    1. When the value of \(x=2\), what is the value of \(f(x)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 12

The correct answer is 12.

    1. When the value of \(x=3\), what is the value of \(f(x)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 21

The correct answer is 21.

    1. When the value of \(x=5\), what is the value of \(f(x)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 45

The correct answer is 45.

  1. Now, answer questions a–d to analyze the function defined by \(f(x)=x(x+4)\).
    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The \(x\)-intercepts for function \(f\) are \((-4,0)\) and \((0,0)\). These points have an \(x\)-coordinate that makes the output value 0.

    1. What is the value of the \(x\)-coordinate in the vertex of the graph?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -2

The correct answer is -2.

    1. What is the value of the \(y\)-coordinate in the vertex of the graph?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -4

The correct answer is -4.

    1. What is the vertex of the graph of function \(f\)? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The vertex appears to be at \((-2,-4)\). From the tables, the function values seem to change from decreasing to increasing at those points.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 32

The correct answer is 32.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 21

The correct answer is 21.

Enter your answer here.

  1. Now, answer questions a–d to analyze the function defined by \(g(x)=x(x-4)\).
    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The \(x\)-intercepts for function \(g\) are \((0,0)\) and \((4,0)\). These points have an \(x\)-coordinate that makes the output value 0.

    1. What is the value of the \(x\)-coordinate in the vertex of the graph?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 2

The correct answer is 2.

    1. What is the value of the \(y\)-coordinate in the vertex of the graph?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -4

The correct answer is -4.

    1. What is the vertex of the graph of function \(g\)? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The vertex appears to be at \((2,-4)\). From the tables, the function values seem to change from decreasing to increasing at those points.



  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course.
    1. Plot the points from the tables on the same coordinate plane. (Consider using different colors or markings for each set of points so you can tell them apart.)

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

    1. Make a couple of observations about how the two graphs compare.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  • The \(x\)-intercept of both graphs is at \((0,0)\).
  • The graphs seem to be a reflection of each other across the \(y\)-axis.
  • The vertices both have a \(y\)-coordinate of -4 and also mirror one another across the \(y\)-axis.
  • Each function mirrors itself across a vertical line through its vertex.

page.title: 7.11.2: Self Check
page.contents:
The table for function \(f\) is below. What is the vertex of the graph of \(f\)?

\(x\)

-3

-2

-1

0

1

2

\(f(x)\)

0

-1

-3

-1

0

2

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is an \(x\)-intercept. The answer is \((-1, -3)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the \(y\)-intercept. The answer is \((-1, -3)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The graph mirrors itself with the points \((-2, -1)\) and \((0,-1)\), so it appears that \((-1, -3)\) is the vertex of the parabola.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is an \(x\)-intercept. The answer is \((-1, -3)\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.11.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Determining Parts of a Graph from a Table

Identify the \(x\)-intercepts and vertex of the quadratic from the table:

\(x\)

-5

-3

-1

0

1

\(f(x)\)

16

0

-2

0

16

The \(x\)-intercepts are where the \(y\)-values are 0.

This occurs at \((-3,0)\) and \((0,0)\).

The vertex occurs where the function will create a mirror image, or be symmetrical for all points. This often occurs halfway between the two zeros (when there are two zeros).

For this function, the vertex is at \((-1,-2)\).

Try It: Determining Parts of a Graph from a Table

Determine the vertex from the table:

\(x\)

5

6

7

8

9

10

\(f(x)\)

0

4

8

4

0

-2

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine the vertex from the table:

The zeros are located at \((5, 0)\) and \((9, 0)\). The vertex will be halfway between the two zeros. This occurs at \(x = 7\).

The point in the table at \(x = 7\) is \((7, 8)\).

This is the vertex.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.11.3: Sketching a Graph of a Quadratic Function Using at Least Three Identifiable Points
page.contents:
Activity

  1. The functions \(f\), \(g\), and \(h\) are given. Refer to these functions to complete questions a–f.

Equation

\(x\)-intercepts

\(x\)-coordinate of the vertex

\(f(x)=(x+3)(x-5)\)
  1. _____
  1. _____

\(g(x)=2x(x-3)\)
  1. _____
  1. _____

\(h(x)=(x+4)(4-x)\)
  1. _____
  1. _____


    1. Predict the \(x\)-intercepts for function \(f(x)=(x+3)(x-5)\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x\)-intercepts for function \(f\): \((-3,0)\) and \((5,0)\)


    1. Predict the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for function \(f(x)=(x+3)(x-5)\).

Enter your answer here:

Correct! 1

The correct answer is 1.


    1. Predict the \(x\)-intercepts for function \(g(x)=2x(x-3)\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x\)-intercepts for function \(g\): \((0,0)\) and \((3,0)\)


    1. Predict the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for function \(g(x)=2x(x-3)\).

Enter your answer here:

Correct! 1.5

The correct answer is: 1.5.


    1. Predict the \(x\)-intercepts for function \(h(x)=(x+4)(4-x)\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x\)-intercepts for function \(h\): \((-4,0)\) and \((4,0)\)


    1. Predict the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for function \(h(x)=(x+4)(4-x)\).

Enter your answer here:

Correct! 0

The correct answer is 0.



  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Graph the functions \(f\), \(g\), and \(h\): 

    \(f(x)=(x+3)(x-5)\)
    \(g(x)=2x(x-3)\)
    \(h(x)=(x+4)(4-x)\)

Use the graphs to check your predictions. Then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

  1. Without using technology, sketch a graph that represents the equation \(y=(x-7)(x+11)\) and that shows the \(x\)-intercepts and the vertex. Think about how to find the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex. Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The \(x\)-intercepts for \((x-7)(x+11)\) are at \(x=7\) and \(x=-11\). The vertex for \((x-7)(x+11)\) is halfway between the \(x\)-intercepts, at \(x=-2\). If the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is -2, then the \(y\)-value is \((-2,-7)(-2+11)\) or -81. The vertex is at \((-2,81)\). The \(y\)-value when \(x=0\) is \((0-7)(0+11)\), which is -77. The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-77)\).

Video: Sketching a Graph of a Quadratic Function 

Watch the following video to learn more about sketching a graph of a quadratic function using at least three identifiable points.



Extending Your Thinking



The quadratic function \(f\) is given by \(f(x)=x^2+2x+6\).

  1. Find \(f(-2)\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

6

  1. Find \(f(0)\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

6

  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph of this quadratic function?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

-1

  1. Does the graph have any \(x\)-intercepts? Explain or show how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, the graph does not have any \(x\)-intercepts. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is 5 because \(f(-1)=(-1)2+2(-1)+6=5\). The coefficient of the squared term is positive, so the vertex is a minimum, which means the output of the function is never less than 5.

page.title: 7.11.3: Self Check
page.contents: Find the coordinate of the vertex of \(f(x) = (x - 2)(x - 4)\).

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is a zero. The answer is \((3, -1)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The vertex is located halfway between the zeros of \(x = 2\) and \(x = 4\). Substitute \(x = 3\) into the function and the result is \(y = -1\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is a zero. The answer is \((3, -1)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the \(y\)-intercept. The answer is \((3, -1)\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.11.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Graphing Quadratics With Points

The function \(f\) given by \(f(x)=(x+1)(x-1)\) is written in factored form. Recall that this form is helpful for finding the zeros of the function (where the function has the value 0) and telling us the \(x\)-intercepts on the graph representing the function.

Here is a graph representing \(f\). It shows two \(x\)-intercepts at \(x=-1\) and \(x=3\).

If we use –1 and 3 as outputs to \(f\), what are the outputs?

  • \( f(-1)=(-1+1)(-1-3)=(0)(-4)=0\)
  • \(f(3)=(3+1)(3-3)=(4)(0)=0\)

Because the inputs –1 and 3 produce an output of 0, they are the zeros of the function \(f\). And because both \(x\) values have 0 for their \(y\) value, they also give us the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph (the points where the graph crosses the \(x\)-axis, which always have a \(y\)-coordinate of 0). So, the zeros of a function have the same values as the \(x\)-coordinates of the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph of the function.

The factored form can also help us identify the vertex of the graph, which is the point where the function reaches its minimum value. Notice that the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is 1, and that 1 is halfway between –1 and 3. Once we know the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex, we can find the \(y\)-coordinate by evaluating the function \(f(1)=(1+1)(1-3)=(2)(-2)=-4\). So the vertex is at \((1, –4)\).

When a quadratic function is in standard form, the \(y\)-intercept is clear: its \(y\)-coordinate is the constant term \(c\) in \(ax^2+bx+c\). To find the \(y\)-intercept from factored form, we can evaluate the function at \(x=0\), because the \(y\)-intercept is the point where the graph has an input value of 0:

\(f(0)=(0+1)(0-3)=(1)(-3)=-3\)

Try It: Graphing Quadratics with Points

Find the zeros and vertex of the function \(f\) given by \(f(x)=(x-4)(x+2)\). Use the points to graph \(f\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the function’s zeros and vertex:

Step 1
Set each factor equal to 0 and solve.

  • \( x - 4 = 0, x = 4\)
  • \(x + 2 = 0, x = -2\)

Step 2
Write the zeros as points.
\((4, 0) (-2, 0)\)

Step 3
Find the \(x\)-value halfway between the zeros.
\(x=1\)

Step 4
Substitute \(x = -1\) into the function to find the vertex.
\(f(1) = (1 - 4)(1 + 2) = (-3)(3) = -9\)
Vertex: \((1,-9)\)

Step 5
Now, use these points to graph \(f\):

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.11.4: Graphs of Quadratic Functions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The function \(f\) is given by \(f(x)=(x-2)(x+4)\). 

Without using graphing technology, answer questions 1–4.


  1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph representing \(f\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x\)-intercepts for function \(f\): \((2,0)\) and \((-4,0)\)


  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! -1

The correct answer is -1.

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! -9

The correct answer is -9.


  1. What is the \(y\)-intercept?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-8)\), because \((0-2)(0+4)=(-2)(4)=-8\).



  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Sketch a graph that represents \(f\).

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The graph opens upward with vertex at \((-1,-9)\) and \(x\)-intercepts at \((2,0)\) and \((-4, 0)\).

page.title: 7.11.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Select two true statements about the graph that represents \(y=2x(x-11)\).

Correct! Its \(x\)-intercepts are at (0,0) and (11,0).The \(x\)-coordinate of its vertex is 5.5.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: Its \(x\)-intercepts are at (0,0) and (11,0). The \(x\)-coordinate of its vertex is 5.5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Select two equations whose graphs have a vertex with \(x\)-coordinate 2.

Correct! \(y=(x-1)(x-3)\) and \( y=x(x-4)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are: Its \(x\)-intercepts are \(y=(x-1)(x-3)\), \(y=x(x-4)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Three different equations are given. Refer to these equations to complete questions a–f.

Equation

\(x\)-intercepts

\(x\)-coordinate of the vertex

\(y=x(x-2)\)

a. _____

b. _____

\(y=(x-4)(x+5)\)

c. _____

d. _____

\(y=-5x(3-x)\)

e. _____

f. _____

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents \(y=x(x-2)\)?

Correct! \((0,0)\) and \((2,0)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((0,0)\) and \((2,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph that represents \(y=x(x-2)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents \(y=(x-4)(x+5)\)?

Correct! \((-5,0)\) and \((4,0)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((-5,0)\) and \((4,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents \(y=(x-4)(x+5)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -0.5

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -0.5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents \(y=-5x(3-x)\)?

Correct! \((0,0)\) and \((3,0)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(0,0)\) and \((3,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph that represents \(y=-5x(3-x)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1.5

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1.5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Answer questions a–c about the function \(y=(x-2)(x-4)\).

Correct! \((2,0)\) and \((4,0)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: \((2,0)\) and \((4,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Is \((-1,3)\) a point on the graph?

Correct! Substituting -1 for \(x\) gives \((-1-2)(-1-4)\) or -3 -5, which is 15, so \((-1,15)\) would be a point on the graph, not \((-1,3)\).

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is No. Substituting -1 for \(x\) gives \((-1-2)(-1-4)\) or \(-3 \cdot  -5\), which is 15, so \((-1,15)\) would be a point on the graph, not \((-1,3)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Does the graph represent the equation \(y=(x-2)(x-4)\)?

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.11.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

YThe correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.11.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Graph a quadratic function given in factored form.
  • Find the vertex and \(y\)-intercept of the graph of a quadratic function in factored form without graphing it first.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.11.1: Finding Coordinates
    • In this activity, you determined the missing values of coordinates given a function and a graph of a quadratic.
  • 7.11.2: The Factored Form of a Quadratic Expression and the X-Intercepts of Its Graph
    • In this activity, you were given a quadratic function in factored form. You used this function to complete a table and determine the \(x\)-intercepts and vertex of the graph of the function.
    • 7.11.2: Self Check
    • 7.11.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.11.3: Sketching a Graph of a Quadratic Function Using at Least Three Identifiable Points
    • In this activity, you continued to determine the intercepts and vertex of a quadratic and used these points to graph the quadratic function.
    • 7.11.3: Self Check
    • 7.11.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.11.4: Graphs of Quadratic Functions
    • In this activity, you once again identified specific points from a quadratic function and used them to graph the function.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.11.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
